Taiwan, known for its legendary culinary scene, has amazing food for every budget and preference. Yen, located within the W Taipei, is a solid choice for people wanting to try something out of the ordinary Chinese, yet remains true to its traditional roots. I curated the set menu myself for our family, and couldn't be happier with every single dish. The Peking Duck is very well prepared, rivals the one at Le Palais Taipei, and many high caliber, Michelin star worth establishments around the world. The staff hand carves the duck and hand wrap each piece for us. One particular incident I remembered from this meal was during the carving the chef accidentally dropped a piece of the duck onto the floor. (I've never seen this happen in my life) He then went back to the kitchen, and returned with a single piece of duck to add it into our dish to compensate. I thought that was...interesting. Although all the dishes were amazing, the particularly special dishes for me included the taichi crab steamed egg, the pepper fried dragon tiger grouper, and the king crab rice soup. The taichi crab steamed egg is perhaps the best chawanmushi/steam egg I have ever enjoyed in my life. they utilized the crab innards for the yellow side, and crab meat for the white side, separated with a green chain of chopped zucchini, all set on top of a silky smooth, crab dashi infused steamed egg. The result is a work of art that contains multiple layers of flavoring, intense and light, depending on the side of the dish you are eating. The dragon tiger grouper is typically steamed. The chef chooses deep fry means he is quite confident he isn't going to overdo it, and he did just that. The fried coating is thin and not overpowering, enables me to taste the fish's freshness, but at the same time, flavored with multiple layers of Chinese pepper corn, weaving numbing and spicy sensation velvety together. The king crab rice soup has a bit of a theatrics to it. Named after China's ancient beauty Xishi, the dish comes to the table with the broth and rice separated. The rice has both regular and rice crispies. When they pour the king crab bisque into the hotpot containing the rice, steam rises and rice crackle, with the steam meant to represent Xishi enjoying her bath. The dish had such an intense king crab aroma and flavor, made it irresistible to be licked clean. YEN in W Taipei has taken Chinese cuisine to a new level, by maintaining their traditional flavors and turn them into work of art. I highly recommend anyone to give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

They sat me at a nice window seat and gave me all the attention that any diner would appreciate. They were super attentive, friendly and just overall fantastic. I don't think I could have asked for better servers and host. My server (a young man with red/orange dyed hair) was very accommodating and professional. I would go back just for the super service. I chose a prix fixe for lunch which was very reasonable for about $50, and for dinner I had their famous Kao Ya (roast duck), bbq pork belly, and tiger prawns. It was a lot of food but I just had to try them. They were super delicious! And honestly, for the ambience, service, and food the price was really great. I would return to YEN on my next trip back to Taipei.

It's not our first time dining at Yen restaurant W Taipei. We had such a wonderful and memorable experience on the first day so we went for lunch again on the next day. We were being greeted almost instantly by Manager Benvo by addressing our name. We not sure if it's his special arrangement , he then seated us at another side of window table where Bunny our favorite server was in charge at that section on that day. Bunny was sweet enough for remembering our preference of fresh cut chili with soya sauce for my partner and without sauce for me. Let me first start by saying I am a Taipei resident so I have never stayed at W Taipei's rooms. This review is about the hotel's WOOBAR and Wedding services. Since I'm a local, I've been quite a few times, but I always only go when friends visit from out of town. I must say the bar's atmosphere is great, and the decorations are top notch. The second time I went, I was served warm beer again. I'm not sure how a 5-star hotel can have so much trouble stocking enough beers since it wasn't even a crazy holiday like New Years Eve. I then ordered Whisky Sour, and the bartenders failed miserably in making it. Ever since, I've resorted to the fail safe - Whisky on the rocks. But seriously, if you're from out of town and need a place to drink, there are a ton of places within a few minutes walking distance. Go to Brown Sugar, inHouse, Element, Stream, Barcode. Go next door to Meridien's Quube. Any of those places top WOOBAR. Now about the wedding services. I am planning on getting married next year and had thought about hosting it at W since the hotel's location simply can't be beat. So this morning around 9am I called up W Taipei, and it rings for a minute or so. No one picks up. I wait 5 minutes. Call again, and this time someone picks up, and transfers me to Wedding services, which ends up being voice-mail letting me know they'll call back. I leave my information, what I need, etc. No one calls back. My fiance calls again in the afternoon. No one picks up. She calls again in the afternoon and gets transferred to another phone which no one picks up. I'm not sure why W Taipei has such a distaste for simply picking up the phone. This is definitely not the standard of service a W hotel should have. We're done calling. We'll host the wedding some place where someone will actually pick up the phone. Even McDonald's picks up the phone when I call for delivery.

My 2nd time visiting here. Again, food is amazing. Service is consistently great. They surprised me with the private dining room and the birthday cake. Very appreciated. Great shout out to Eason, our service that day. He brought us a lot of joy!

After discovering our hotel had no restaurant and all the local eateries were cash only and we had some trouble determining the spice levels in local dishes we decided to try something out of character. The staff is well mannered. Surprising no need for tip? They do the special dance hoe down. Its quite entertaining on top of the food. Great selection on steak and drinks.

The reception, and the service was outstanding. Though we didn't have a reservation, the desk found us a table very quickly. We were served by Ben, who couldn't have been more helpful. They should have been with the dessert, not as a starter! We wanted to eat the bread with our salad, but couldn't, as it was so sweet. Washed our mouths out with the excellent draught Taiwan Beer, then carried on without bread. Sadly, the salad could have been good, but was covered with that weird orange artificial cheese that Americans use for cooking. Guys, cheese should be made from milk - not from homogenised fats + colouring in a factory! We had to go through the salads & pick it all off before eating. Our sirloin steaks came. They were tasteless, and definately NOT sirloin. Sirloin has a rim of fat round the edge, and threads of fat running through the meat. We know a bit about steaks, as we keep beef ourselves! These were tasteless, fatless, perfectly formed pieces of meat. See my photo below. Google sirloin steak for yourselves and see what it should be. I can only guess these were pieces of topside beef, shaped and cut in a mould of some sort. Both our pieces were identical twins - whoever saw 2 identical sirloin steaks before? To be fair though, they were both cooked exactly as we had asked - 60 deg. Then the 'Texas Fries' - damp, soft and soggy. We both had to leave them on our plates. My wife who knows a thing or two about potatoes says that a) they used the wrong variety - the same variety they were using for mash. You cannot make fries from this! and b) the fat wasn't near hot enough to crisp them. So, all in all, they need to promote the house manager, and sack the head chef.

I was staying at the Grand Hyatt, so I enjoyed 4 breakfasts and one lunch here. The place is very busy; there are often queues, sometimes with ropes to aid their formation. The caf√© serves breakfast, lunch, dinner and afternoon tea. Note breakfast is for hotel guests only, all are welcome at other times. Prices are higher on weekends. At breakfast, Western and several types of Asian cuisine (Taiwanese, Chinese, Indian, Japanese) are offered, and the selection is plentiful, with minor variations each day. I came at the 6:30 am opening time each day, when the queue was just for waiting for the doors to open. After checking your name and room number, you are escorted to a table and instructed to adjust the "Available/Occupied" card on your table accordingly. The clearing of dishes and tables was very efficient, as turnover is high. Food was of good quality. Everything is serve yourself, including coffee from those fancy machines. The queue forms immediately for the omelet/fresh egg station, but goes quickly. There can also be a wait for the made-to-order noodle bar. At lunch, you are checked in and seated without the occupancy card. I made a reservation for lunch, but this is probably not required. Your check is brought to you when it appears you are nearly finished. Again, the bountiful options include Western (including prime rib) and Asian, with many Japanese seafood and sushi selections. You can see the chefs slicing huge slaps of fish beginning during the breakfast hours. Many of these Japanese choices were also seen at the buffet at Irodori, the Hyatt's Japanese restaurant, where I also dined. The dessert bar included a chocolate fountain. Beer on tap is offered. Seating is nicely separated into multiple dining sections, with a variety of seating/table styles. There are restrooms within the restaurant. A very pleasant and filling dining option, especially for hotel guests.

We stay at the Grand Hyatt Taipei a lot!! This place is amazing for business breakfast or for a family meal. There is a wide variety of offerings from Western, Chinese, Japanese, Salads, fresh pastries and fruit. All the food is delicious and the ambience is bustling. But the best part of The Caf√© is the service. Each morning, when we head downstairs for breakfast, we are greeted by Elsa. She calls us by our first names (with permission) and always greets us with a hug. She had taken the time to get to know us, where we like to sit, and she even notices when we are not there. She is such a great ambassador for the Grand Hyatt. As we watch her work in the restaurant, we have noticed that she builds relationships with many of the guests who frequent the Grand Hyatt. We have chatted with many and we all feel the same way about Elsa. She makes you feel AT HOME, even when you are far away from your friends and family.

There were 3 dining times to choose from; lunch, afternoon tea and dinner. This review will cover the afternoon tea. Afternoon tea is from 3pm~5pm, it is the cheapest of the 3. The price is NT$865 per person (EZ table exclusive offer), service fee included. The original price is about NT$1,100 per person service fee included. 1) seating: The seating is too close and crowded. The spacing is not even an arm's length away. We sat at a 2 seat table. 2) Service and atmosphere; The service is good. the staff is friendly and service speed is fast. 3) Food; The food selection is great; there are dim sum, Chinese food, Indian food, some Taiwanese dishes, Japanese food, and some generic western dishes. The desert is great, I think it's better than many buffet at this price range. If your dinning purpose is celebrating birthday you get a birthday cake for free, you can either eat it at the spot or take it home with you. Overall I recommend it, it's one of the few buffets I think that's worth visiting again, only at a discount price. There are better choices to choose from at the NT$1,100 range.

My mother-in-law made a reservation for New Years Eve here for the entire family and paid full price to secure it. About ten days before the event, they called her and told her that the price of the dinner had doubled. She did not want to do this so she asked them to cancel and they agreed and told her they will refund her the dinner. New Years Eve comes and they call her to tell her that since she did not show up for dinner, she will be charged. We ate here with some local friends and were impressed with the place as it was bustling and had a great display of food on offer. The food is mostly fresh seafood and salads with Thai food and desserts. The starter was the best because there was a really large selection of fresh cooked and raw seafood. I really enjoyed the cooked prawns and crabs and some salad but many of the foods such as raw shellfish was not my cup of tea. I would have liked to have seen some raw tuna and salmon but there wasn't any. For the main course the food is most Thai and Taiwanese. I am a big fan of Thai food so really looked forward to eating here. However, the choice was not great and I found the sauces of the tom yum and green curry to be a little disappointing and less spicy than I like. Also in the green chicken curry the pieces of chicken were large pieces that included the soft skin and gristle and bone when I prefer to have lean pieces of chicken so had to do a lot of fiddling around on my dish when eating. Desserts were alright, quite a good display, but mostly we ate ice cream ..... several portions. The drinks were self service in metal beakers and my favourite was the mango lassi, which had a hint of pineapple and coconut. My kids liked the Thai tea and kept going back for more. Our local friends had several plates of the fresh seafood and less of the Thai food. So in my opinion if you love to eat raw and cooked seafood then you can really enjoy this buffet, but it you are looking for traditional Thai food then perhaps this isn't the place to come. This is a really nice buffet restaurant and seemed to be very popular, fantastic for seafood and worth the visit.

The genius of Joel Robuchon is that he took the classic French cooking that he grew up with and reinvented it for the modern age. He created a mash up of a sushi counter with a tapas bar and added sleek, cool design and the L'Atelier concept was born: Small portions of intensely flavoured food that are somehow reminiscent of the past, yet ultra-modern. The decor is all black and red and chrome, with high chairs and a long counter. The chefs work in an open kitchen and have direct contact with the customers. For me this is foodie heaven. For others maybe less so - perhaps that explains some of the strange negative reviews here. If you love food, then ignore these people and go. Soon. It is expensive of course although the set lunch and dinner menu's are good value. The kind of ingredients they use don't come cheap and this level of quality doesn't either. Expect to pay upwards of NT$ 4-6000 a person, more if you splash out on their speciality Sea Urchin dish - which I highly recommend! Olivier Jean is the new chef here. He came from L'Atelier Etoile in Paris and he brings the same relentless focus on quality that all Robuchon prot√©g√©s have. They are never quite satisfied with how things are and always looking to improve. The food is excellent, at least as good as L'Atelier in Paris (which has 2 Michelin Stars) and better than London IMHO. What's different here is that it is all a little less formal, a little less stiff, and I found I enjoyed it more. The staff were wonderful, a great balance of effortless professionalism and a playful sense of fun. If you are someone that loves to eat. Someone for whom a meal is an occasion to be celebrated. Someone who appreciates the skill and commitment of a great chef, then I highly recommend you go here. You won't regret it.

I brought a newly wed couple friends of mine to try out the restaurant and we left with unforgettable memories of the good food and services. From starters (we had 2 which came with the set) to main (I had saffron infused risotto and a meat dish of beef), they are executed to perfection. I heard this one is the least expensive among all Robuchon chain. Thus if you wanted to pay less for the same experience, you should visit taipei branch. It situated in a very nice building. The look is standard. Dark with stylish furniture. We went for lunch over Chinese New Year. Restaurant didn't charge more instead they just pulled the cheapest lunch set out of their menu. For 2880 NT, you can have two appetizers and two main course. Desert, coffee were also included. We found the portion of food quite generous. Over all the dishes are good. Waiters are very attentive. I love my fried fish and roasted chicken. You may not think its value for money but theres at least no complaint. The place was fully booked that day to our surprise. Which means its well loved by many.

I love the Jo√´l Robuchon bar seating concept where, as a lone traveller, I am able to interact with the waiters, the sommelier and the chef whilst watching the kitchen at work. The restaurant's dark black and red interior seemed warmly inviting and the kitchen the true heart of the restaurant. I chose the menu devouverte and every dish was without fail a true success. An amuse bouche of foie gras mousse with port sauce and parmesan foam was rich, unctuous and surprisingly light. What a lovely way to start a meal! A caviar first course was an interesting little tin of caviar over a crab and lobster mouse with a lovely gel√©e of I think apple and chill. Lovely yet subtle with the little pops of caviar acting almost to tantalise the tastebuds. A second course of girolles served with crispy ravioli and onion foam was a wonderful way to show case the fantastic girolles. The mushrooms were beautifully cooked and the foam and accompanying sauce played off the rich earthiness of the mushrooms to superb effect. A third course of pan fried foie gras, I was almost dreading. Most restaurants either choose bad quality foie gras or simply over cook the foie gras leaving it moist and revealing the underlying liver taste. This was quite the opposite. The foie gras was perfection and complimented beautifully by little stewed grapes and lovely blueberry sauce whose combined bitter and sweet tastes left much thought as I was eating this course. A fourth course of maine lobster with seasonable vegetables and lobster bisque was beautifully cooked. The lobster was sweet and rich and the accompanying lobster bisque was velvety and surprisingly light. A fifth course of John Dory consisted of a beautifully cooked piece of fish surrounded in a beautifully sophisticated saffron and clam sauce. The accompanying cabbage and kale was a fantastic use of two very much maligned vegetables. A sixth course of quail stuffed with foie gras with mashed potato was an exquisitely presented dish. The quail was matched in flavour by the beautiful mashed potato which was quite simply one of the silkiest, smoothest and creamiest mashed potatoes I have ever eaten. The quail itself was beautiful and gamey. However a special mention must be given to the accompanying herb salad which both complimented the beautifully cooked meat and added an intensity and complexity to the mashed potato. Looking round the restaurant the alternative main course of hanger steak with shishito and bell peppers must get a mention - it looked fantastic and I shall have to try it next time. A seventh course of pineapple served in several ways was a fantastic palate cleanser and was a great preparation for an eight course consisting of a simply beautiful mango cake that was a nice light way to complete the meal. I would say that it was disappointing that there were no half bottles and the list of wine by the glass was small. However, the wine list itself is well conceived an I enjoyed a wonderful white chateauneuf du pale whose complexity and age complimented this simply fantastic meal.

Actually they have chef stations for sashimi/sushi, grill, tempura and teppanyaki, even the special "taiyaki" dessert, so food never sits there for too long. For me, the highlights were their beef steak cubes and many of their grill items. Price wise, I can't say it's worth the original price. But if they have promotional discounts, then I can recommend giving it a try.

I've recently become a frequent guest of the Grand Hyatt Taipei, itself a very good hotel. I've tried several of the hotel restaurants, and as I love Japanese food (am half-Japanese, can cook Japanese, and my wife and I often travel to Japan for a foodie trip), thought I'd give the Irodori Grand Hyatt a try. To be fair, it's a Japanese buffet, so I set my expectations accordingly, but even so, was generally disappointed - in the food, the ambience, and the waitstaff. Taipei certianly has some good buffet restaurants, but at over USD$52.00 for lunch, Irodori is way over-priced for the low-quality of food overall. It all looks great, but the fish for sushi/sashimi are cheap cuts, very little color, no taste. The noodle bar could be great, but it wasn't, they didn't even have the essentials to make a bowl of Japanese-style Ramen. I tried the Soba and Udon, both over-cooked and mushy. The broths had no depth. The limited Yakitori selection was over-cooked and dry. The Chawan Mushi was too stiff. Oddly enough for an Asian restaurant, though they had a variety of prepared rice dishes, no plain white rice was on the buffet line. I had to ask for it, by the time it arrived, pretty much everything I had that was a hot dish wasn't any more. The restaurant is very noisy, not somplace to enjoy a leisurely or relaxed meal. What annoyed me more than anything was being watched and treated like I was going to dine and dash without paying my bill. I was asked my room number when I sat down. I was twice told that I must ask for my bill before leaving. Adding insult to injury, my bill was presented before I was done, without my asking and the waitress stood there until I had signed it. Over-priced, only average food, waitstaff that stalk you, noisy, I won't be back. And please note, the other buffet restarurant in the hotel is a good value, with excellent service.

Cause you pick your own toppings and softness ect: it comes down to your taste then and im still trying to nail the perfect tonkatsu flavour for my tastbuds but again happy with what i got but i shouldve went a bit stronger but the noodles were perfect for my softness chosen.
Kid loved hes ramen and was happy with hes and extra pork provided by me.
Gift shop of ichiran noodle packs on offer just before paying did get the 2 pack instead of the usual 5 packs as the price difference between japan and taiwan is about double which i couldnt justify paying knowing its cheaper.
Again the ramen prices for our meal are double plus from japan i reckon and cost for two ramens a 2 pack and the extra pork/egg was around 1300TWD/$71AUD which other then a tourist trap and a kids faviroute i wouldnt go out of my way to come back when other places are better at a fraction of the price over asia but the serentity of eating in quiet stalls is always good

We had heard stories about this restaurant prior to coming to Taipei and we were determined to try it for ourselves. This resulted in an amazing lunch that's recommended to anyone interested in different travel experiences. Firstly there is the line to enter, do not let it deter you as it moves quickly. You complete the order form ready for when you are taken to an individual cubical. Pass the completed order form to the noodle chef who will then prepare your fresh ramen bowl as ordered. The bowing from the chef is a nice touch. The meal was brilliant, and this was a fantastic experience that we will repeat on our next trip to Taipei.
I have to say that even here in Taipei (apart from Shibuya and Dotonburi that I've tried) has a long queue when dining. Almost the same Ichiran dining experience feels, only in Taipei, not in Japan.
Wonderful food!! The lines are long, but the Ramen is so worth it. It's a must try place! I eat here every time I'm in Taipei

We enjoyed the ramen. Other than the 2 hours waiting time, the rest of the experience was splendid ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Get a Q number, do not lose it. You can proceed elsewhere while waiting and check the Q status from your phone. Once number is near, go back to shop, show your Q number and get ready for your Ichiran experience üòã

Terrible and child unfriendly . We were walking past when we were ushered in, and was told that a kid's meal would be provided , however after ordering and finishing our own meal , the kids meal hasn't arrived yet. It was only after inquiring did they tell us we were ineligible because we were tourist ,which was not at all mentioned to us beforehand. As you can see, the child is just sitting here in the kids chair , anticipating to eat with the bib on, but blatantly denied the meal.

We come very often. It is the same ramen as what we can get in Japan. The broth, ramen, spice, pork slice, green onion, seaweed and soft heart egg also steamed rice are all the same, delicious & unforgetable.

We come quite often because it is very authentic & very delicious. It isn‚Äôt easy to bring the authenticity to go abroad but it does. The noodle is great, the broth is delicious, the thin BBQ pork is yummy & seaweed, soft yolk egg and extra ordered chopped green onion bring the whole ramen experience a perfect one.

Came over to the Ichiran at Taipei because I could not get it back at Singapore. I must really say I am impressed with the concept as well as how consistent the taste were.

I tried quite a few outlets at Hong Kong, Japan and now Taiwan and the taste has been the same. Maybe to give some tips for diners is that now they are very high tech, you can just get a queue number first and then you can monitor the queue status via your phone, once you are about 10-20 numbers away you can start making your way back to the Ichiran shop and the waiting time should be pretty fast.

If they ever ask you if you are okay to split, just say yes as you will be dining on your personal space anyway!

Overall, must drop by if you have the time! But if you want to get your local Taiwanese food fix, and you have basically tried Ichiran before, this can be skipped.

I am at the Grand Hyatt Taipei on business and had a craving for ramen. It‚Äôs January and a bit chilly in Taipei and some hot delicious soup sounded really good. I went in search of a ramen spot in ATT but wasn‚Äôt impressed with my findings. I saw Ichiran listed as a nearby ramen spot and thought I‚Äôd give it a try. You know you are into something when you walk up and there‚Äôs a line and a restaurant worker outside checking people in. I waited for about 10 minutes and then was seated in an individual booth. By the way, all of the booths are for solos so it turned out to be the perfect spot for this lone traveler. Coming from the US, this is an experience. A special and memorable moment unlike typical food experiences I‚Äôm used to. But the best part is that the food actually matches the hype - the line, the folks taking selfies, the thousands of reviews on Google. It is indeed worth it. The most delicious ramen broth I‚Äôve had. I‚Äôm no expert on ramen but I do like good food and have had many ramen bowls over my lifetime. It‚Äôs clear this stuff is special and in a league of its own. Definitely worth a visit.

Long line here on a Saturday afternoon, was told to wait for 2 hours but you can sit outside and enjoy the Taipei 101 view from afar. Even if you don‚Äôt wish to wait there, they provide a QR code on the ticket paper that you can scan and check the queue number. Once you‚Äôre inside you sit in these solo-booths and they serve you from this small wooden window. I quite liked this concept and it was nice to see something different like this. The food is great, we enjoyed the ramen although I haven‚Äôt tried the restaurant in Japan so I can‚Äôt make comparisons. However everything was just nice for me and I really enjoyed it.
Taste just exactly like the one in Tokyo. All of us love it and have additional egg and the meat on the side. The soup is just remarkable.

Nice ramen broth with thin tender pork slices. Up your spice level. Good first experience eating in own booth but rather expensive as not table seating with service. Recommended to try if not too long queue.
Have tried the Ichiran in Japan (Osaka and Nagoya). Wasn't disappointed. Atmosphere is similar, food just as good except find the ramen slightly overcooked. But still enjoyed very much. Satisfied.

The dedicated tableside service staff was kind and professional. She also remembered the last time I had a meal here. The single bottle of red wine she recommended was also very good. The food recommendations were also great. The food tasted very good and the overall dining experience was great.

The main objective for this lunch was the prime rib and to that topic specifically it was great. Lawry's of course is an established establishment and the quality of food will always be steady in terms of the meat. But, I must say the starter courses are far below what I expected, and to be honest, I wasn't expecting much.

The soup was way too salty (beef vegetable soup), the crab cakes lacked flavor and the "greens" underneath the crab cakes were shriveled and wet (probably not stored properly?), lawry's spinning salad is normal cant mess up sauce that comes in a bottle.

All in all, the meat is good, for the first serving go for the thickest cut, but since after the first serving every serving after the rarity of the meat can not be chosen, it will come out as medium or more, so I would suggest to get the 7.5oz thin cuts.
Prime rib was extra delicious that day. It was cooked well for medium rare thin or with bone. We had a lovely romantic night except for a few baby crying and kids wondering around events.

The price and the meal, the atmosphere, the service are not equal to the American restaurant experience

1. Beverage before meals: The texture of sweet roots and vegetable juice is not fine enough, and the taste is slightly rough.
2. Salad: Selected vegetables are common, sauce flavor is flat, can not stimulate appetite.
3. Soup and front dishes: the taste of mushroom sauce is still good, but light, lack of level feeling; Hokkaido dried beet size is small, taste is normal, and expectations differ, it is not recommended to select.
4. Main meal - ribs: Although the portion is full and the visual effect is good, but when the actual taste, after removing fat meat, many parts are still resilient, even if you choose three-point cooking, the meat has not reached the expected softness, chewing is very hard.
5. Main meal - Boston shrimp: The appearance is refined, but the shrimp meat is old, the taste is ordinary, and the overall taste is not in proportion to its high price.
6. Drinks and desserts: moderate performance, no impressive highlights.
7. Service and atmosphere: The restaurant's service and overall atmosphere are the most amazing part of this dining experience. Since this is our first visit, booking time is 13:30 and arrival is on time. During the meal, the servant's dish fell in awe, and the dish was filled with fragments. After the main meal was finished, it was only 15: 00, the servant began to accelerate the checkout in an implicit manner, and the overall meal time was urgent and bad.

In summary, according to the standards of international American luxury restaurants, the Taipei Shinjuku restaurant still has considerable room for progress in the communication skills of the staff, crisis handling, attitude to service and the quality of meals, so that it can match its pricing.

The overall quality of the food is lower than before and the service at times was not great. Food wise our appetizers were cold when we got them, the taste was okay but being that it was a hot appetizer you would expect it to be warm at least. The french onion soup used cheddar cheese which made it felt cheap and when we saw it i was a bit surprised and confirmed it was cheddar cheese which beforw it wasn‚Äôt. The taste def was affected by it. The prime rib is still the star of the mean but lawry‚Äôs sides are always a highlight but I was disappointed in the quality of the sides, either just on the warm side and the taste def was not as great compared to before. Service, they were rushing every course which at one point got really annoying I was eating my salad and had the fork in my hand and my waiter came over and asked if he can take it away. We were stunned and I had to tell him it is very obvious i am still eating. I felt the meal was rushed and i cudnt even enjoy my conversations with my friends bc they wud just randomly interrupt without caring that we were in the middle of a conversation. I hope with the move to bellavita in oct they will re-raise the quality.

The restaurant is located inside the Dame Department Store. It has convenient parking and is close to the MRT City Hall. The decoration design style is high-end and the atmosphere is very suitable for celebrations. High-quality ingredients and good service attitude

The service was good and the waiters were very nice, went there for 6 months anniversary and they had a cake prepared for us also sang a song. in the end they made us a hand made card. overall it was a good experience finding there.

My first time I am visiting this restaurant. "Price is what you pay. Value is what you get" (Warren Buffet). The quality of the service, the coziness of the room, and the excellency of the food are what I experienced during the meal. You will feel this whenever you are (in Taiwan, US, or Singapore). Great and congrats to all...

The elegant environment is suitable for parties with children
The service staff is nice and very careful
Enjoy great meals for adults and children
The furnace meat makes eating a very double group of people
All to meet their own preferences

I like to give some sort of positive review if possible whenever I visit somewhere and enjoy at least some part of the meal.
Unfortunately last night at Lawry's didn't have very much positive to talk about.
We arrive a little after 8pm for dinner and were told before we were seated there was no more prime rib but we could order anything else on the menu.
Odd. No prime rib at a prime rib restaurant?
Hmmmm.
But we decide to venture in anyway. Mistake.
We order steaks.
Then we noticed the prime rib serving cart was still making rounds through the restaurant, happily serving prime rib to hungry patrons.
When our dinner was served, my Wagyu steak ordered medium came to the table almost bleeding rare. I had to send it back.
My friend's aged steak came out looking like a flat iron steak and wasn't cooked right either.
It should also be noted the restaurant was only about 10% full. Far more open tables than full.
At this point we were feeling like this was a hidden camera gag on us because the prime rib serving cart was still in motion, serving everyone else in the restaurant except us.
We sat in amazed confusion as this just kept on happening at the few tables near us.
Then, the manager approaches our table and inquires if our steaks will be enough food because, TA DA!! there is still prime rib available, and would we like some?
Really? Unbelievable.
We told the manager to please walk away from us so we could stew in stunned silence at what had just happened.
At this point we felt it would be best to ramble on so we asked for our check and again we were sadly surprised to see not a single item had been taken off them tab, no concessions of poor service or our bad experience.
Paid the bill and swore off Lawry's forever.
I will never return.

First impression is woah! Friendly and sophisticated serving, pleasant ambiance, clean and neat, but unfortunately the compliments end here. I was rather disappointed afterwards.
"The famous spinning salad", seriously? Nothing but a cheap show off and you end up with a basic tasteless salad. The roasted beef was nicely done but a bit fatty for my taste.
The food and service were good as usual. There were lots of birthday and anniversary celebrations around us, so it might be a good idea to place business luncheon away from celebration parties.

The Lawry's prime Rib (raost beef) was alright. The spinning salad was a gimmick. Tasted alright, but silly or touristy. Quality didn't match the price. The mashed potatoes were flavorless. Almost tasted like powdered potatoes. The creamed corn or whatever it was, was also flavorless and slightly awful, tasted very unhealthy, I mean what is it? Then the Lawry's fllavored shaker pepper and salt?! Oh my, at a fancy restaurant they have that crap. Iodine salt? No fluer de sel. No pepper grinder mill. With the service and price there should have been someone with a long pepper mill grinding for me and some special gourmet salt. They try to be high-end but they look low class with those stupid shakers on the table. Ya think they could make some new labeling looking gourmet or tasteful.
Food is ok, but the price performance is not that good~

Din Tai Fung is a culinary masterpiece! From the first bite of their legendary dumplings to the flavorful Dan Dan Noodles, every dish is a taste sensation. Impeccable service and a warm ambiance make this spot a must-visit for food lovers. In a word: exceptional!

It's what you expect. A lot of tourists and if you unlucky, the waiting time can be real long. So the food is totally good and enjoy it. Some of the things is really hot so don't burn yourself. The one with truffle is my favorite and i always go for this dish...

This is the original restaurant at yongkang street. It has more ambience since the look and furniture are original when they opened. Like the other branches, it‚Äôs a wait during all hours , and a long wait during peak hours

Stumbled across this place when I investigated why there was a big crowd of people. There was a long wait, but as a single I was sat right away. The menu is big, prices are very reasonable for a Michelin star rated restaurant. Staff was great. Food was on outstanding. Not sure if you could about d let new if you were in a group, but it was an excellent experience.
Reservations were made by Taipei friends, who ordered all the courses. Excellent service, delicious food. Excellent acoustics in the room, so conversation easy.
A few branches in taipei and the irony is there are more branches overseas Besides the famous dumplings, the chicken/wine appetiser, chicken soup are also good Service is excellent

Xialong Bao, Xialong Bao, Xialong Bao!!! Theo only thing that constantly comes back to me is Xialong Bao at at Din Tai Fung. Reviewers compliments other restaurants and said some to be better than Din Tai Fung but I disagreed. We tried at least 4 other top rated restaurants from budget to mid range pricing, but did not any that actually matched Din Tai Fung's Xialong Bao. The service was very good too. The waitresses really took care of us as we went from one dish to another in confusion. Din Tai Fung would still be our first choice next time.

When I think of Taiwan I always think of xiao long bao. This place is a perfect machine for these things. The workers work with precision, like intense robots. The service is fine, but the server was rushing and spilled beer on my LV bag and myself, but more than made up for it by the apology, a free beer, some pineapple cake, and dessert bao. The food is actually really delicious and the xiao long bao are to die for!

Probably going to be the next export thing from Taiwain to the world. Already in China and Australia. The food and setup is great. If kitchen labor cost would be as favorable in the western world I guess it would be the next, and healthier, McD.

This has to be on anyone who visits Taipei, just so you can see for yourself if they truly are the best dumplings in Taiwan. For me, another restaurant took that title, but Din Tai Fung was still excellent. A bonus is that we arrived at 8 and the two of us did not need to queue, because we were willing to share a table upstairs. Pork Xiao long bao, prawn chilli dumplings, prawn dumplings, braised pork and noodles, and water spinach. All delicious and mouthwatering. Complimentary green tea is provided, which is a nice touch. Bill came to 1300 NTD all in for 2 which is excellent value for the quality.
A little expensive for a foodie who loves street food but worth a try especially their xiao long bao.
Yes, Din Tai Fung has overseas branches but I think it is more authentic to have Din Tai Fung in Taipei. I have had all the Din Tai Fung quotas before leaving Taipei.
Good restaurant and the dumplings don't have a overwhelming taste at the same time packs the flavor. However they need to accept credit card like other stores

And it's because the food is always high quality and delicious. Even though it's a chain, it's well worth going to any of the branches, and while there are plenty of other places for xiao ling bao, the restaurant chain is justifiably renowned.

Came here in the afternoon tea setting. For my money, luxury Chinese food doesn't get much better than this place. The photos speak for themselves. Unlimited sushi with varieties like botan ebi, wagyu, hokkaido scallop, and king salmon, what else can one ask for? (ok maybe hamachi). The lamb chops, tiger shrimps grilled/tempura/garlic fried were all absolutely amazing. Having chawanmushi done inside a whole egg shell topped with salmon roe is not just flavorful but also like a work of art. The clam chowder with a super crunchy pastry on top was my choice of seconds, while the peking duck also didn't disappoint (I had a full sized leg to myself!) The dessert section looked like a fancy pastry shop from Paris, while the drinks section featured many exclusive alcohol and tea, of which I favored a rose oolong tea. Just by writing this review I feel the need to go back again!

Excellent variety of choices, a five-star dining experience where most of the stations were staffed, and courses made fresh on the spot, rather than the typical heat-lamps. Seafood steamed in front of you, hand rolls made to order, souffles fresh out of the oven, more choices than we had a stomach for! Beautiful views and atmospheres high atop the Breeze Building. Attentive staff and enough variety for anyone. The experience defies description. I found this to be the best anywhere I've had on the planet.

Food was mediocre, view was amazing, good drink options (moonlight and starry night), reservations are a must and sometimes difficult to get. Have your hotel or a friend assist in booking, I emailed them and was able to get reservations. Otherwise just a one time hit, won't be coming back.

Had a great 2023 Holiday dinner at Inparadise. The buffet itself took up the entire floor of the building. It spanned 360 degrees. A diverse range of food stations - examples included: raw/sushi, seafood, steam table, grill, desserts, etc. Definitely a focus on seafood but lots of other options as well. The sushi station was of higher quality than your typical buffet.

The food is very diverse and delicious, and the environment is also very good. Although the price is not cheap, the CP value is very high, even better than the buffets in many five-star hotels. I come here often if I have the opportunity.

Food is really a BUFFET ceiling. I have eaten at many places, but the dishes are really rich. There are so many choices and almost none of them are Lei‚Äôs meals. Moreover, you can see the night view of Taipei City by the window. This quality is perfect!! The only drawback is that it's really hard to locate and the phone calls often don't go through.

The food was excellent. The decor is basic and serve its purpose. Great view. Great value for the food and experience. Overall rating 4.0 out of 5.0 comparing to other global world class buffets. 5.0 rating buffets are Bacchanal and Wynn at Las Vegas.
LOVELY VIEW ESPECIALLY WHEN IT IS ON A 64TH FLOOR. DIFFICULT TO MAKE A BOOKING AS I WAS TOLD THAT THEY ARE ALWAY FULLY BOOKED
Great selection, quality, view at a reasonable price. One of the best high end buffet in Taipei. Great for family or with friends. To try.

We had a great time the first day after we arrived after a long flight to Taiwan. We booked about a month ahead and were able to get window seats. The staff was very courteus, the food delicious with about 4 different buffet areas, and of course the view was great. It was definitely a treat.

The previous for us was eating lunch, this time we make our reservation two months before over the phone and we finally succeeded. The food remains their standard and no big difference between day and night, the main reason for the night was you can non stop eating for four hours starting from 5:30pm. The congee and the sushi bar still my favorite, and if the food in teppanyaki can remain hot when serving the customers will be much better.

This place was fabulous, the views, food and service. Located on the 46th floor, every table had a exceptional view of Taipei. The food was a real delight from the fresh seafood to the duck. I'll be going back to this place again!

One of the nicest place to eat in Taiwan. I enjoyed the many choices of fresh seafood. I normally don‚Äôt like buffet but this place was an exception. The reason being of all the exotic seafoods. For 100 bucks a person it sure was worth the value.

Our daughter-in-law invited us to have buffet lunch. The restaurant is situated on the 46th floor with a 360 degree panoramic view of Taipei. It has a capacity to accommodate a few hundred patronage. Despite that you had better make a booking beforehand as very often you will miss out by its full-house situation. Foods are splendid and fantastic. They range from very fresh seafoods of various kind from king prawns, fresh raw fish, crabs, and abalone in the seafood section! Oriental foods such as Japanese sushi and tampura ring the changes of your appeitite on the other end of list. Carvery is good too with steaks, pork, lamb and different kinds of hams. There are many types of dishes suitable for vegetarians and vegan options, and exotic ones such as real bee honey hives is among the display of various types of desserts! Drinks are plentiful and being served with assorted cocktails, beers, freshly brewed coffee and tea. Lunch buffet starts at 11.30am and finishes at 2.00pm. The time we went the restaurant offers special at NT$1200 per person! It was an excellent occasion to dine along with our in-laws from Taipei and a glimpse of the panormaic 360 degree view of Taipei from the 46th floor. It was a very good occasion for family gathering!
Attended a large group lunch meeting on January 17. Food choices, taste, quality, and presentation were excellent. High praise to the head chef and entire food staff. Definitely worth visiting.
Well-educated waitstaff provided high-quality service. Friendly and professional service stood out. A nice place worth returning to occasionally.
Excellent Italian food at a very reasonable price. Nice and friendly service. Loved the place and atmosphere.
Hotel amenities and location were great, but breakfast food variety was disappointing. Limited options and slow service. Expected more for a five-star hotel.
Food was average, but service quality was very poor for a fine dining restaurant. Did not meet expectations for the price.
Breakfast was nice overall, but guests had to prepare their own coffee, which felt unusual for a five-star hotel.
Some dishes were good, especially the salmon. The chicken was dry and only average.
Food variety was acceptable but lacked refinement. Main courses were disappointing compared to other options in the area.
Excellent dining experience with high-quality food, elegant service, and a pleasant atmosphere.
Atmosphere was strong, but food execution and service repeatedly failed. Main course issues were poorly handled and disappointing.
Seafood was not as fresh as expected, and dessert variety was limited and underwhelming.
Excellent afternoon tea buffet with standout items such as apple pie, foie gras, and souffl√©.
Location was convenient, but food and service did not provide a strong reason to return.
Excellent breakfast experience with a great juice corner and omelet station. Staff were warm, attentive, and helpful despite the busy atmosphere. Service and food quality were outstanding.
Very wide buffet selection with seafood, roasts, pasta, Japanese, Chinese, cheese, and an impressive dessert bar. Extremely popular and often fully booked. Reservations strongly recommended.
Good variety of food including fruits, salads, and desserts. Clean restaurant with good service. Sparkling water would be a nice addition.
Did not meet international five-star expectations. Lunch selection was more limited than dinner, beverage service was inconvenient, and service organization was poor. Overpriced for the experience.
Fresh seafood and enjoyable dessert selection. Overall good quality for a buffet experience.
Dinner buffet offered a large variety of dishes and drinks. Although pricey, the experience was worth it and very satisfying for a family meal.
Food quality and selection were limited for the high price. Service was poor and staff attitude was disappointing. Not worth the cost compared to other options in Taipei.
Large buffet with global cuisine options, but nothing stood out as exceptional. Noisy atmosphere and not worth the price compared to local restaurants.
Excellent Christmas buffet with high-quality food, tender meats, and outstanding service. Staff were attentive and professional. One of the best buffet experiences in Taipei.
Buffet was overrated with limited selection and mediocre seafood. Did not live up to its reputation given the price and long reservation wait.
Buffet was spacious and clean but food quality did not justify the price. Many items felt frozen and lacked freshness.
Very large seafood selection including premium ingredients. High quality but also expensive compared to other buffets.
Atmosphere and service were good, but food lacked a wow factor. Price felt high for buffet-quality dishes.
Excellent service and fresh food across multiple buffet stations. Upscale atmosphere with strong variety and well-sized portions.

Modern Thai restaurant in a shopping center. Green curry was decent, but Pad Thai lacked authentic flavor and was too salty. Food arrived very fast, but the restaurant was noisy and the cleaning station in the center was distracting.
Very good food overall. Fish in lemon sauce, scallop salad, and chicken curry were especially delicious. Disappointed that wine could not be ordered by the glass even though it was listed.
90-minute dining limit and gets crowded on weekends. Good food and pleasant ambience. Reservations are recommended.
Good Thai flavors and a nice atmosphere. A popular choice and suitable for group gatherings.
Fast serving speed with stable food quality. Dishes arrived quickly and diners were not rushed when the restaurant was not busy.
Tasty food with good service. Would return again to try different dishes.
Interesting menu with a mix of Thai and non-traditional dishes. Standard items were fine, though authenticity varied. Good service overall.
Good option for treating friends or family. Portions were generous and food was good, but special celebration requests were not acknowledged.
Friendly staff with quick and responsive service. Food was tasty and the restaurant is worth trying.
Consistently good food and service across multiple visits. Quality met expectations each time.
High expectations due to location, but flavors lacked balance and freshness compared to other Thai restaurants in Taipei.
Friendly service and very good food, though dishes were slightly too spicy. Overall a great dining experience.
Excellent steakhouse experience comparable to top US steakhouses. Wonderful service and high-quality dry-aged steaks. Highly recommended for steak lovers staying nearby.
Filet mignon was delicious. Staff were attentive and the restaurant atmosphere was comfortable and not too noisy. A good place for dinner.
Staff spoke English well and provided great food and service. Would definitely return when visiting Taipei again.
Lunch set menu was reasonably priced. Food quality was good and service was decent.
Steak and French onion soup were acceptable, but service was inconsistent. Felt more like a family-style restaurant than a fine steakhouse. Expensive for the experience.
Long wait despite arriving early due to large reservations. Food wait time was nearly two hours. Service was polite and apologetic, but the long wait affected the experience.
Food quality remained excellent. Pan-fried scallops were fresh, porcini cappuccino was flavorful, and steak was the highlight. Excellent service and a great lunch experience.
Outstanding dining experience with a premium set menu. Wagyu ribeye steak was exceptionally tender and flavorful. High-quality oysters, bread, and wine pairing. Worth every penny.
Fresh ingredients cooked properly with superb service. Very convenient location with parking available.
Good execution of a classic white-tablecloth steakhouse. Service and food quality were strong, though prices were high. Overall a good steak dining option in Taipei.
Surprisingly good steakhouse located in a mall. Premium meat selections were excellent, buffet and dessert options were a nice bonus.
Steak and side dishes were good. Salad and bread stood out. Location inside a department store made the environment noisy. Wine by the glass was expensive. Service was fast and friendly.
Delicious food and attentive service. A perfect place for celebrating a birthday and worth the price.
Enjoyable first visit with friendly staff and good seating. Lamb chops were excellent. Service was efficient but felt rushed at the end of the meal.
Wagyu Australian beef was excellent and extremely tender. Would return again for steak when visiting Taiwan.

Large all-you-can-eat hot pot buffet with abundant meat, seafood, vegetables, drinks, desserts, and ice cream. Mala soup was aromatic and not overly numbing. Clean, fresh, and good value for eating a lot in one meal.
High-quality beef and prawns at a reasonable price. Not gourmet dining but very satisfying hotpot experience. Ice cream was a nice finishing touch.
Excellent hotpot experience with plenty of ingredients. Orders delivered by robot. Unlimited Movenpick and Haagen-Dazs ice cream. Sauces and drinks were self-serve.
Limited dining time but good variety of toppings. Large selection of desserts and ice cream. Fun experience for families with kids.
Wide selection of meats, seafood, condiments, drinks, and desserts. Spacious layout with built-in induction tables. Service was fast and efficient.
Poor service with ordered dishes not arriving despite reminders. Food quality was acceptable for the price, but service was disappointing.
Buffet-style hotpot with optional premium beef or prawn upgrades. Large selection of food, drinks, and Haagen-Dazs ice cream. Reservation required due to high demand.
Vegetable broth option available. Items ordered from menu with free-flow drinks and premium ice cream brands. Buffet limited to two hours. Reservation recommended.
Overrated and not cheap. Aside from the Haagen-Dazs ice cream, the food was ordinary and nothing stood out.
Very good value buffet with wide variety of food and beverages, including free-flow beer and wine. Two-hour limit was sufficient. Highly recommended.
Excellent spread of meats, seafood, vegetables, drinks, and desserts. Ala carte buffet style allows unlimited ordering. Soup bases were flavorful and suitable for family meals.
Popular hotpot chain with good variety, sauces, drinks, and ice cream. Meat quality was average compared to other hotpot restaurants. Reservation advised.
Nice atmosphere with a very good food selection. Plenty of vegetarian options and a wide range of desserts and ice cream. Would return again.
One of the best value all-you-can-eat hotpot options in Taipei. Strong meat quality, large variety of food, drinks, and desserts. Multiple soup base choices.
Excellent value all-you-can-eat hotpot with prime beef and premium ice cream brands. Two-hour dining limit was sufficient. Very enjoyable experience.
Food was amazing with reasonable portions and good service. Dishes felt more authentic than many Italian restaurants usually experienced by travelers.

Outstanding gluten-free options for guests with celiac disease. Staff were knowledgeable and accommodating, including cooking guest-provided gluten-free pasta. Excellent service and a memorable dining experience.
Food was average and served at room temperature. Garlic sauce lacked flavor and dishes were drenched in olive oil. Would not return.
Very good food with great service and pleasant atmosphere. Chicken parmesan stood out as the best dish. Prices were fair and portions generous.
Food was good overall, but service was slow and disorganized. Long wait times caused food to arrive at different times and get cold. Probably would not be the first choice next time.
Excellent food, service, and prices. Pizza was especially good. Friendly, welcoming atmosphere and would definitely return.
Wonderful Italian restaurant with tasty food and excellent service. Would definitely return.
Lovely decor with murals, tasty food at reasonable prices, and excellent service. A very enjoyable dining experience.
Great food with fast and friendly service. Garlic knots and spaghetti with meatballs were especially good.
Located in a strip mall but with a nice atmosphere. Good service and flavorful Italian food at a fair price.
Excellent food and service. Generous portions, especially pasta dishes. A highly rated local restaurant worth visiting.
Mixed experience. One diner disliked the sauce and meatballs, while another found the food acceptable. Service was friendly but language barriers were noticeable. Unlikely to return.
Hidden gem away from tourist areas. Large portions, fair prices, and friendly service. Menu offers something for everyone.
Pizza lacked sauce and cheese and felt overpriced. Additional credit card fee was unexpected. Crust was good but overall experience was disappointing.
Excellent lunch with hearty portions at fair prices. Spaghetti carbonara and sausage sub were both delicious.

Very disappointing experience. Afternoon tea pricing was misleading and resulted in a bill over 2,000 NTD for minimal items. Guests felt misled by staff explanations and pressured to leave positive reviews in exchange for free snacks. Not worth the price and would not recommend.

Impeccable high tea experience with excellent tea preparation and attentive service. Staff carefully introduced tea options and food was well presented. One of the best authentic afternoon tea experiences in Taipei.
Very nice tea with excellent service and a warm atmosphere. Slightly expensive, but acceptable for Taipei.

Extremely overpriced with poor food quality. Drinks were basic but expensive, food was badly executed, and dishes were returned. Experience felt misleading and not worth the high price. Strongly do not recommend.
Enjoyable British-style tea experience with fresh baked cookies and milk tea panna cotta. Friendly and attentive service enhanced the visit.
Restaurant appeared closed during visit and replaced by another concept. Unable to dine as planned.
Confusing concept combining French, British, and Italian elements. Service was good, but food was underwhelming and drinks were expensive. Did not fully live up to its reputation.
Delicious pasta with flavors reminiscent of Italy. Restaurant is tucked away but offers great food and excellent service.
Unique interior design with a wide alcohol selection. Rice dish was very good and service was attentive and friendly.
Strong service and above-average food quality. Wide tea selection and thoughtful service details created a relaxing atmosphere. Recommended for afternoon tea.
Quaint and relaxing place with large portions and excellent food quality. Service was outstanding and staff were patient and personable.
Cozy and quirky atmosphere. Limited menu focused on pasta and risotto. Food was acceptable and service was good. A pleasant but not exceptional experience.
Did not meet expectations despite high ranking. Limited menu, high prices, and lack of full kitchen. Would not return.
Outstanding service and attention to detail. Set menu was generous and memorable. Unique atmosphere made this a standout dining experience in Taipei.
Excellent afternoon tea experience with generous service. Staff and owner were very welcoming, creating a memorable and celebratory atmosphere.
Lovely Sichuan cuisine at a reasonable price with a delicious numbing sensation typical of Sichuan food. A great find.
Excellent restaurant and considered the best Kiki branch in Taipei. Very delicious food, good atmosphere, and kind staff.
Tasty food, kind staff, and clean restaurant. Overall a very good dining experience, though one dish was served late.
Set menu dishes were good but very spicy. May not suit diners who do not enjoy spicy food.
Good food and pleasant atmosphere. All dishes were delicious and the family was very satisfied.
Good atmosphere and food quality. Some entrees were served late, but the overall experience was positive.
All dishes were delicious and service was satisfactory. Would like to visit again.
Atmosphere, location, and food were all satisfying. Service was especially memorable and welcoming. Would return on a future visit to Taipei.
Excellent location near Taipei 101. Cozy seating, great service, and very good food.
Friendly manager, excellent tofu dish, good service, and tasty food. Highly recommended.
Reservation was made but there was a short wait. Overall experience was good, and sea bream was especially delicious.
Arrived earlier than reservation time and was warmly welcomed. Ordered individual dishes instead of a set menu and found the food excellent with very kind service.
Very satisfying first meal in Taiwan. Spicy and flavorful dishes met expectations, and staff were friendly despite the restaurant being crowded.
Food was delicious, but portions felt crowded and the restaurant was quite loud. Still an enjoyable meal.
Food was very good and staff were kind and welcoming. Dining environment felt comfortable, and reservations were not necessary.
American-style restaurant located in Breeze Xinyi. Cheeseburger and fish and chips were well prepared and good quality. Excellent service and reliable dining experience.
Extremely poor experience. Long wait due to waiter forgetting the order. Food arrived without explanation or apology, and celery served was rotten. Lost appetite completely.
Celebrated a birthday and were very pleased with the friendly and helpful staff. Enjoyable experience and would return in the future.
Delicious food and friendly service. Birthday celebration included staff singing and a festive Christmas atmosphere. Family enjoyed the experience and plans to return often.
Very good food selection typical of TGI Fridays. Service was friendly, professional, and attentive.
Enjoyable family gathering with good food and drinks. Pleasant lunch experience overall.
Staff were responsive, but food quality was mediocre and caused stomach discomfort. Poor meal pacing with starters and mains arriving out of order.
Great place to meet friends. Comfortable booths, good food, pleasant ambience, and reasonable prices.
Convenient location above Taipei City Hall bus station. Good option when visiting Taipei 101 and nearby attractions.
Good service, tasty food, and nice ambience. A reliable dining option with consistently satisfying meals.
Dependable American food such as ribs and calamari. Food quality was good though service could be slow due to crowds.
American fast-casual chain offering ribs, steaks, burgers, beers, and cocktails. Straightforward and familiar dining experience.
Excellent service with attentive staff. Food quality was good and overall dining experience was very positive.
Affordable pricing with good service. Menu updates were appreciated and suitable for family gatherings.
Enjoyable American-style meal with generous portions. Fish and chips were tasty and suitable for sharing, and drinks were refreshing.
